origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Men's Glee Club.

did.unittitle: Men's Glee Club (University of Michigan) Records 1886-2012
did.abstract: University of Michigan choral group founded in 1859; includes correspondence, administrative records, musical scores, publicity material, photographs, posters and sound recordings in addition to digitized versions of records and born digital audio, video, and still images

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Records have been received in periodic accessions since 1960. Included in the collection are records received in Dec. 1985 (donor # 3624), and records received from Philip Duey in Dec. 1979 (donor # 6409). Additional recordings and material from the 2012 trip to China were received in 2012.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Men's Glee Club (University of Michigan), Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: As early as 1846 University of Michigan students met regularly to sing "for pure enjoyment." In 1859 the university formally acknowledged this activity through the establishment of a Glee Club. Michigan's group was the second such college organization formed in the nation.

In its early days the club included from seven to twelve singers who performed college songs, humorous vaudeville numbers and skits. In the 1870s the larger group began to divide into smaller performing units, trios and quartets, which allowed for greater individual recognition. In the 1880s the club began to tour and in 1884 the organization made its first excursion outside of the state. Because of the demands of touring the size of the club was expanded, first to sixteen members, four men per part, and by the turn of the century to around fifty members.

After World War I the club experienced difficult times. A lack of sound musical programs led to declining audiences, and in 1920 a disastrous West Coast tour lost so much money that the club was unable to tour for five years. In 1921, as part of an effort to revive itself, the club became part of the Michigan Union. In 1922 the name "Men's Glee Club" was formally adopted and the club experimented with new music. An all classical format was first adopted, and when this proved unsuccessful it was changed to the balanced program of classical, humorous and college songs still used today. The club also began to formally participate in the annual Michigan Union Operas, an all male comedy review.

All of these changes led to a revival in the club's fortunes. Touring was resumed, which eventually caused the club to withdraw from the Union Operas, because the two groups' separate touring schedules made it impossible for members to participate in both. In 1943 the club formally ended its affiliation with the Union and resumed its prior status, as an independent student organization.

After World War II the club evolved new traditions and expanded its touring activity. In 1952 the club began the Fall custom of singing with the Glee Club of a school that had played the University of Michigan that day in a football game. In 1955 the popular double quartet, the Friars, was first organized. 1955 also marked the club's first European tour, which was followed by international tours in 1959, 1963, 1967, 1971, 1978, 1989, and 1992. The tours of 1959 and 1963 were highlighted by victories at the International Musical Eisteddfod in Llangollen, Wales. 2012 saw the club embark on a successful tour of the People's Republic of China.

When the club was first organized, and for many years thereafter, musical directorship was entrusted to a club member. In the 1870s and 1880s, however, the club began to experiment with hiring a professional director, usually a music teacher from the Ann Arbor area. In 1894 the club returned to appointing one of their own members as director, but the idea of hiring a professional remained and in 1908 the club resumed the practice of hiring a director.

chronlist.head: Professional Director's of the Men's Glee Club

scopecontent.p: The records of the Men's Glee Club date from 1886 to 2012 and were received in several major accessions. The first accession, covering 1886-1985 and 1991, includes four linear feet of manuscript, printed, and photographic material as well as posters, scrapbooks, and sound recordings in a variety of formats. The first accession has been divided into five series: Chronological File, Philip A. Duey Material, Photographs, Sound Recordings, Scrapbooks, and Archived Website.

The 1995 accession of the records of the Men's Glee Club were comprised of two linear feet of correspondence, photographs, and topical files ranging from 1919 to 1994. Items of particular interest include a folder of historical writings, which provides anecdotes, reflections, and facts about the club prepared for an exhibit on club history. The Press Releases folder is also of note, as it reflects information given out by the club to newspapers and other media of the towns they visited. Both of these folders are found in the Topical series. The records of this accession are divided into 3 series: Correspondence, Topical, and Visual Materials.

The 2010 accession to the University of Michigan Men's Glee Club records is organized into one series. The Sound Recordings series, 1952-1987, (10 linear feet) is comprised of University of Michigan Men's Glee Club concert recordings, including its annual fall and spring concert series. Many of the boxes of tape reel also include a concert program and concert set list.

The 2012 accession consisted entirely of digital materials (scanned images, audio files, video files, and still images) that added content to the Chronological Files series and established a China Concert Tour series.

did.unittitle: Chronological File

scopecontent.p: The Chronological File represents the basic records of the collection. Arranged by academic year, it consists primarily of printed concert programs, newspaper clippings and other publicity material, occasional financial records (generally summary statements of club finances for an academic year), details regarding tours (particularly the annual spring tour), and minutes. Many posters were included in the Chronological File. Unfolded posters have been housed separately in an oversized folder. This series contains four individual documents of particular note. A fifteen page club history written by John Payne is found in 1958-1959. Narrative logs of the club's international trips in 1955, 1959 and 1967 were maintained and are filed in the appropriate years. Chronological File materials from 1886-1969 have been scanned and these digital versions may be found in the Bentley Library's digital repository.

The 2012 additions to the Chronological Files series include digitized images of content in the first two boxes of the series, spanning the years 1886-1969. Glee Club members scanned this content as part of an organizational project in 2011. Digital versions of Laudes, the official newsletter of the Men's Glee Club, were also part of the addition. These newsletters were published biannually and span the years 2000-2011 (with the Fall 2009 issue missing from the accession). Both the original and digital copies have been retained.[BHL deposit ID: 87250_0002]

Philip A. Duey

scopecontent.p: The Philip A. Duey Material consists of only two folders, one detailing the radio career of the Club's one time director before he came to Ann Arbor and the other containing miscellaneous personal material. A few newspaper clippings about Duey before he came to the University of Michigan are found in the appropriate chronological folder, particularly 1946-1947.

did.unittitle: Radio Career
Miscellaneous
Photographs and Posters (see also boxes 5, 6 and 8)

scopecontent.p: The Photographs (some oversize) consist primarily of group pictures, tour pictures, photos of the Novelaires and the Friars, Philip Duey photographs, and a few Union Opera pictures. A few photographs are also located in the Chronological File.

Sound Recordings

scopecontent.p: Sound Recordings include tape recordings made in 1952 and 1967 of club songs, a long playing record album of the 1959 club centennial spring concert, and a 1991 compact disc comprised of concert recordings.

physdesc.physfacet: 33-1/3 long play disc of Centennial Concert

did.unittitle: "Michigan Songs" circa 1978
1988-89 (live recordings)
Photographs and Posters
Photos
Photos
Correspondence

scopecontent.p: Arranged chronologically by season, the Correspondence series mostly reflects the negotiations the club's business manager conducted to secure appearances for the club. The bulk of the letters come from the early 1920s, with two additional folders from the late 1930s. The "1923 West Coast Trip" folder gives the most accurate representation of the often arduous process taken to secure dates and venues for tours. Of note is a letter of thanks from President Gerald R. Ford

did.unittitle: 1923 (West Coast Trip)
Gerald R. Ford 1975
Topical

scopecontent.p: The Topical file deals largely with items documenting the tours upon which the Men's Glee Club frequently embarked. The performance contracts, though not complete, provide a useful and extensive overview of the types of places, venues, and dates the club played and the terms and conditions they demanded. The "Constitution and By-Laws" folder gives an overview of Glee Club policies and administrative operations. The folders in the "Tours" subseries are comprised of materials the club put together in preparation for travel and include itineraries and guides to their destinations.

Visual Materials

scopecontent.p: The Visual Materials series gives a view of club activities from several different eras. "Group Portraits" show the Glee Club posing for photos and contains photos of the club singing or performing other activities. The "Publicity Shots" provide an interesting window to the era when the Glee Club participated in the all-male Michigan Union Operas. The record group also holds an extensive number of color snapshots with negatives of the club's 1987 tour. An oversized folder of publicity posters forms another section of visual materials. Two photo albums and a film of the club's 1964 appearance on the Perry Como television show round out the series.

scopecontent.p: The Sound Recordings series, 1952-1987, (10 linear feet) is comprised of University of Michigan Men's Glee Club concert recordings, including its annual fall and spring concert series. Many of the boxes of tape reel also include a concert program and concert set list.

China Concert Tour 2012

scopecontent.p: In May 2012, the Men's Glee Club embarked on a two-week concert tour of the People's Republic of China that included visits to Beijing (May 3 to May 5), Xi'an (May 5 to May 8), Chongquing (May 8 to May 11), Wuhan (May 11 to May 13), and Shanghai (May 13 to May 16). The resulting China Concert Tour series is organized around the itinerary and includes digital images shot by club members in various locales, audio and video footage of performances at major stops and video of various excursions in host cities. The series is organized according to the Glee Club's itinerary; through : Of note is the concert performance given at Ba Shu Secondary School (Chongqing)and visits to notable sites such as the Great Wall, Tiananmen Square, the Forbidden City, and Olympic Park (Beijing).
